page.title: 14WORSTON MILL
page.content: Worston Mill was built in 1814 by John Milner as a water-driven corn mill. Milner also owned an adjoining silk mill. However, when the adjacent railway was built in 1850 the vibration of the trains broke the silk threads or the glass needles used in this mill. It closed and was demolished in 1890. Worston Mill is a typical mill of the area of its time, having 3 floors and an attic, and being built of unglazed red brick and tile. It was in use as a corn mill until 1970. The present owners acquired the mill in 1972 and restored and extended it as a restaurant in 1981. The mill cannot now be turned by the water as the Water Board took the water rights in the course of 'river improvement'.
